text: Thanks liam. My cert path wasn't correct relative to my working directory.

elements.text: Thanks liam. My cert path wasn't correct relative to my working directory.

text: What I'm not yet seeing is how having certificates makes anything "non-interactive". My old bots just used to have username, password, and application key, then I'd programmatically capture the session token and off I went. Now if I deploy my code to a server I'll (presumably) have to upload a copy of the .key and .crt files with it too, and all this buys me is not having to capture the token.

elements.text: What I'm not yet seeing is how having certificates makes anything "non-interactive". My old bots just used to have username, password, and application key, then I'd programmatically capture the session token and off I went. Now if I deploy my code to a server I'll (presumably) have to upload a copy of the .key and .crt files with it too, and all this buys me is not having to capture the token.

text: It's just for security I think, yeh it's annoying, I keep mine encrypted on s3

elements.text: It's just for security I think, yeh it's annoying, I keep mine encrypted on s3

text: At some point liam I'd love to understand a bit more about how you use AWS. I've just started on it now I've come back to Betfair and already the cost I'm incurring simply capturing price and volume data is looking like it could be optimised. I have the code on EC2 and have tried both MySQL and Aurora for the database. It's this RDS piece that is the highest. I'm thinking automatically dump to S3 on a daily/weekly basis(?), but haven't yet looked at comparative costs of storage.

elements.text: At some point liam I'd love to understand a bit more about how you use AWS. I've just started on it now I've come back to Betfair and already the cost I'm incurring simply capturing price and volume data is looking like it could be optimised. I have the code on EC2 and have tried both MySQL and Aurora for the database. It's this RDS piece that is the highest. I'm thinking automatically dump to S3 on a daily/weekly basis(?), but haven't yet looked at comparative costs of storage.

text: I'll be honest my process changes almost weekly and is more focussed around budget, want to do a blog post on this topic soon. Are you new to AWS? Because you can run a ec2.micro for free for a year which is what I originally did. I now zip and store json in s3 as soon as a market is complete, much cheaper than db storage

I've since taken it down and so I'll see how things level off just collecting new data.
